shotDuration.notes: 8 seconds is the base editorial unit. Water world shots may feel longer due to slow pacing. Volcanic world shots may feel shorter due to faster cuts. Both conform to 8-second generation window.

cameraMovement.philosophy: Two distinct camera personalities matching each world. Water world camera is patient and gliding. Volcanic world camera is dynamic and tracking. Both are deliberate and motivated—never arbitrary.

allowed.description: Water world primary movement. Camera drifts smoothly through water space as if neutrally buoyant. Used for following her observation and small movements.
Water world stillness. Camera holds completely still on her stillness, allowing the environment to move around a fixed frame. Used for contemplative moments.
Volcanic world primary movement. Camera tracks his movement through combat spaces, following his path along bridges and platforms. Dynamic but readable.
Both worlds. Vertical movement revealing scale—height of floating structures, depth of lava below, vastness of water space above.
Both worlds. Slow orbit around character in key emotional beats. Used sparingly for moments of decision or transition.
Both worlds. Slow move toward character for emotional emphasis. Water world: gentle drift closer. Volcanic world: deliberate approach.
Both worlds. Pulling away from character to reveal environment scale. Used for establishing shots and moments of overwhelming space.
Volcanic world only. Camera slightly behind his movement, struggling to keep up during intense action. Creates urgency without chaos.

forbidden: snap cuts within a single shot
rapid back-and-forth cutting within a shot

available.use: Establishing shots revealing full location scale. Water world open chamber. Volcanic world panoramic destruction views.
available.effect: Wide field of view, environmental immersion, sense of vast scale and isolation within space

available.use: Default lens for both worlds. Medium shots of character within environment. Action sequences where context matters.
available.effect: Cinematic widescreen feel with natural perspective. Character and environment balanced. Slight anamorphic flare from light sources.

available.use: Character-focused medium shots. Water world: her face during observation. Volcanic world: his face during pause moments.
available.effect: Natural perspective closest to human eye. Intimate but not intrusive. Clean separation from background.

available.use: Close-ups and emotional moments. Both worlds: detailed facial expression, hands reaching, micro-movements. Key for the final parallel reach shots.
available.effect: Compressed depth, beautiful bokeh from environmental particles (water motes or ember sparks). Isolates character from world.

compositions.use: Mirrored moments between worlds. Both characters in identical center-frame compositions but with opposite physics. Used for direct cross-cutting comparison.
Standard narrative framing. Character placed on one third with environment filling the other two-thirds. Emphasizes relationship between character and world.
Environmental scale shots. Water world: foreground particles, mid-ground character, background architecture. Volcanic world: foreground debris, mid-ground character, background lava glow.
Transitional moments and emotional beats. Character in profile against their world's light source. Water: silhouette against soft glow. Volcanic: silhouette against lava uplight.
Water world corridors and volcanic world bridges naturally create leading lines toward the character. Used for path/journey shots.
Final parallel reach shots only. Both characters in near-identical symmetrical compositions, extending one hand forward. The visual rhyme is the emotional climax.

shotSizes.description: Full environment visible with character as small figure within. Establishes world scale and character isolation.
Full body with substantial environment context. Default for action sequences and movement.
Full body with moderate environment. Transitional framing between action and emotion.
Waist up. Primary framing for character beats. Shows body language and costume detail.
Face and shoulders. Emotional moments, reactions, decision points. Water world: her eyes during observation. Volcanic world: his face showing fatigue.
Single feature (eyes, hand, detail). Water world: her hand testing a current. Volcanic world: his fist clenching then opening. Used sparingly for maximum impact.

depthOfField.philosophy: Use shallow focus for character intimacy and emotional isolation. Use deep focus for environmental context and world-building. Water world tends toward softer, more diffused depth. Volcanic world uses sharper contrast between focused subject and blurred heat haze.

constraints.rule: One action per shot—no multi-event sequences within 8-second window
No scene cuts or location changes within a single shot
Camera movement must be continuous and describable in a single sentence
No cross-references between shots—each prompt must be standalone
Mirrored framing setups must use matching compositions between worlds (center, profile, thirds)
Water world shots default to slower camera speed than volcanic world shots
Cross-cutting between worlds increases in Acts II-III, slows in Act IV
Final reach shots must be nearly identical in framing: centered, medium shot, hand extended forward
Transitions between worlds should be motivated by shared shapes, gestures, or color

notes: The cinematography serves two parallel narratives that never intersect on screen. The camera must be a distinct presence in each world: a quiet companion in the water world, a dynamic pursuer in the volcanic world. Mirrored compositions create the emotional bridge between worlds. Light crossing their faces in parallel moments, interpreted differently by each world's physics. Editing rhythm: cross-cutting increases in Acts II-III to emphasize the mismatch of speed (her patience vs his force), then slows in Act IV to prepare for the final parallel reach. Aspect ratio should feel cinematic widescreen (2.39:1 equivalent).
